Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Leaky integrators?  Going back to a physical analogy, the network graph can
also relate to bond graphs or mechatronic graphs.  The input and output
nodes can exhibit something akin to impedance in an electronic circuit -
depending upon the frequency in which they are activated.  This means (with
a little help from complex numbers) that the connections can emit heat,
which affects the local thermodynamics of the various graph nodes.
 
Is this consistent with your concept of a leaky integrator?
 
Obviously, this adds a bit of computational complexity to the mix - but the
force displacement vectors can be easily computed on graphics processor
unit(s) - which is probably beyond the scope of this thread.
 
Ken Lloyd
 
 


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
petar_chervenski
Sent: Monday, March 17, 2008 10:26 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Re: Spatial & connective CPPNs for Alife domains



I am not using bias node/s for two reasons. One is that I can't find 
a meaningful position for them. The second is that I am going to use 
leaky-integrators. Bias inputs are not well suited for them. I let 
the CPPN output the time constants and bias instead. 
I constrain the experiment to 2D for simplicity. If it proves to be 
interesting, I will extend to 3D easily. This will bump up the 
dimentionality of the CPPN input/output space, though. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, "Ken Lloyd"
<kalloyd@...> wrote:
>
> Peter,
> 
> Yes, I believe this is a powerful idea. In effect the 
perturbations need
> not be a collision, although that analogy works, but can be an 
output from
> other networks.
> 
> There are many things one can do with an intersection of graph
> thermodynamics (including, Fruchterman-Reingold, Kamada-Kawai, 
Eades, etc)
> force directed graph layout and artificial neural networks. Why 
limit the
> interaction in 2D, or 3D space?
> 
> This is a technique I use to model a system network graph in a 
context
> (another system network graph). The input, output and bias nodes 
of the
> system under examination are the interface nodes between the system 
and its
> context. I'm still experimenting with this methodology - in 
between trying
> to earn a living.
> 
> Ken
> 
> 
> _____ 
> 
> From: neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com
[mailto:neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com] On Behalf 
Of
> petar_chervenski
> Sent: Monday, March 17, 2008 9:57 AM
> To: neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com
> Subject: [neat] Spatial & connective CPPNs for Alife domains
> 
> 
> 
> Hi again :) 
> 
> I am developing an Alife pet project evolving 2D mass-spring based 
> creatures. The fitness function can't exactly be defined, since 
they 
> can be evolved towards some tasks like "go there" or something. I 
> want to briefly describe the details behind it. 
> 
> The same network is used for both the body and the nervous system 
of 
> the creature. First the body is built by a spatial CPPN and 
converted 
> to a mass-spring model. There are several tissues (the CPPN outputs 
> tissue type instead of level of expression). One type of tissue is 
a 
> sensor tissue, which excites upon collision. Another type of tissue 
> is a muscle tissue, which contracts the springs when excited. Like 
a 
> regular bilogical muscle. 
> 
> The key point is, that after the spatial CPPN builds the body, the 
> same CPPN is then used for HyperNEAT (additional outputs, though), 
to 
> evolve the connectivity of the neural network controlling the body. 
> Inputs are located on sensor tissue only. Outputs are located on 
> muscle tissue. Hidden nodes are located on the remaining tissue. 
This 
> is essentially evolving both the substrate and the connectivity of 
> the network, but in a meaningful way, because of the geometry and 
the 
> simulated 2D physics space. 
> 
> The simulation is like this - when the sensor tissue is excited by 
> some collision, this also plugs 1.0 into the associated HyperNEAT's 
> network's inputs. When the outputs activation level exceeds some 
> treshold, the associated springs on the muscle tissue are 
contracted. 
> 
> I believe that using the same network for both pusposes (spatial 
and 
> connective) is better than using different networks. Do you think 
> this in general is a good idea? 
> 
> Peter
>
